newsitem.title: USA: NHL, AMERICAN FOOTBALL-DEVILS FINALLY GET BRODEUR HIS 100TH WIN.
newsitem.headline: NHL, AMERICAN FOOTBALL-DEVILS FINALLY GET BRODEUR HIS 100TH WIN.

text.p: The New Jersey Devils finally scored some goals on Tuesday to help goaltender Martin Brodeur notch his 100th career victory.
Bobby Holik and Brian Rolston each had a goal and an assist as the Devils broke out of their scoring slump for a 4-2 triumph over the Boston Bruins.
Rolston and Randy McKay tallied 79 seconds apart early in the second period as the Devils built a 3-0 lead en route to only their third victory in their last 11 games.
Brodeur, who backstopped the Devils to the Stanley Cup in 1995, made 21 saves to snap his personal four-game winless string and reach the century milestone in career victories.
Adam Oates, on a powerplay, and Rob DiMaio scored for the Bruins as Boston pulled within 3-2. But John MacLean's empty netter with 21 seconds to go put the win in the record books.
"I think for our team it was great to win this game," Devils coach Jacques Lemaire said. "We got a couple of goals at the start that helped us with our confidence.

In Pittsburgh, Patrick Lalime tied an NHL record for the best start by a rookie goaltender and Jaromir Jagr notched his league-leading 39th and 40th goals as the Penguins extended their unbeaten streak to 12 games with a 3-1 victory over the Dallas Stars.

Lalime stopped 30 shots to improve to 12-0-2 since being recalled from the minors in early December. His start equals the mark set by the great Ken Dryden with the 1970-71 Montreal Canadiens, who went on to win the Stanley Cup.
Joe Nieuwendyk's powerplay goal was Lalime's lone blemish.
Jagr scored with 5:27 left in the second period to break a 1-1 deadlock and added an insurance tally early in the third.
In Philadelphia, Paul Coffey's goal with 45 seconds left lifted the red-hot Flyers to their league-leading 27th win, a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.
Coffey took a pass from Dale Hawerchuk in the slot and blasted a one-timer past Pat Jablonski for the game winner.
John LeClair and John Druce also scored for the Flyers, who are 15-1-4 in their last 20 games. Brian Savage and Benoit Brunet tied the game for Montreal, which was outshot 35-18.
Coffey's assist on Druce's goal was the 1,049th of his career, moving him into a tie with Gordie Howe for second place on the all-time list.
Ron Hextall needed to make only 16 saves to record his 200th victory with the Flyers.
In Detroit, Kevin Stevens scored at 8:20 of the third period as the Los Angeles Kings rallied from a two-goal deficit for a 3-3 tie with the Red Wings.

Ray Ferraro, who scored the Kings' second goal at 3:36 of the third, nearly won it for Los Angeles. But Detroit goalie Chris Osgood made a blocker save on Ferraro's wrist shot from the top of the crease with one second left in regulation.
Osgood finished with 26 saves for the Wings, who are unbeaten in overtime contests this season at 2-0-8.
Brendan Shanahan's 25th goal, a powerplay tally at 18:28 of the second, had given Detroit a 3-1 lead.
In Vancouver, Alexander Mogilny's goal 8:43 into the third period lifted the Canucks into a 4-4 tie with the Florida Panthers.

Robert Svehla second goal of the game with 14:04 left in regulation gave the Panthers a 4-3 edge, but Mogilny answered with his 18th of the season, whipping a wrist shot past John Vanbiesbrouck's right pad.
Vancouver had a power play for the first 1:56 of overtime, but the Canucks were unable to test Vanbiesbrouck.
Mike Sillinger scored twice for Vancouver, the second on a penalty shot at 5:03 of the third that tied the game at 3-3.
